Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank our opponent, Claudio Fava, for his great work in achieving a common position with the Council, which includes many improvements proposed by our House.
With this Directive, we once again demonstrate our commitment to building a common migratory policy based on a comprehensive approach.
The approach of this Directive is clear: to combat organized crime, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.
We want the unjust miserly wages for immigrants to disappear, and also, those that distort average salaries, especially in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require great courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and large amounts of money involved in the shadow economy.
In precisely difficult times, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows intelligently, with generosity, but also with responsibility.
The easy option would be to give in to the temptation of not attempting to curb the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave around eight million irregular immigrants in a state of vulnerability, with working conditions akin to slavery.

Ladies and Gentlemen, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic and even criminal sanctions in the most aggravated cases are necessary, which have a dissuasive effect on entrepreneurs.
By doing so, we will manage to reduce the shadow economy and eliminate the migratory incentive created by the possibility of working illegally.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is the legal route.
Therefore, we wish to pursue the global approach and call on the Commission, Commissioner, Mr Barrot, to present the new "blue cards" for other employment categories as soon as possible.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislative term with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in 1999, we suffered a major maritime accident, that of the Erika vessel near the French coast, which gave its name to an initial set of legislative proposals aimed at halting and preventing accidents.
We believed we had averted the danger, but soon after, the coasts of Galicia were ravaged by the oil slick, originating from another accident even greater than the first, that of the ship.

Since then, in the Transport Committee, we have been working on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the numerous resistances we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States that rejected our proposals, considering them too demanding.

In these ten years, we have adopted various directives and regulations, some of which we have had to revise again because, due to the cuts promoted by the Council, they were not effective in their original formulation.

We tested the rules for the introduction of double-hulled vessels, the European Fund for major oil catastrophes, refuge ports, and now we review and approve the liability of passenger carriers by sea, the investigation of

maritime accidents, the community system for tracking and information on maritime traffic, port state control, and finally, the Regulation and Directive concerning ship inspection and recognition organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to be able to enter into force and be applied by all member states in the shortest possible timeframe.
That is why I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term ends, I leave Parliament, and I do so with the regret of not having succeeded in making the introduction of existing control systems mandatory.
They are patented to determine when and how many bilge and fuel tank residues have been illegally discharged into the sea by a particular vessel.
That is, a kind of black boxes, sub-seameters that can be inspected by maritime authorities each time a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment better care and stricter procedures to curb the vast amount of pollution we produce. If we fail to do so, it will impact our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not take another ten years to control illegal marine fishing more effectively and efficiently.

Mr. President, the European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European Council on Foreign Relations recognized Mexico as a strategic partner on October 13th, pending the opinion of the Parliament on the matter.
Let us recall that already at the seventh meeting of the Mexico-European Union Parliamentary Commission, held at the end of October last year, we stated that one...
The Strategic Association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We highlight the good moment in relations between both parties and the positive balance of the current comprehensive agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperation matters, especially in the face of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that is shaking our continents.

With the great country that is Mexico, we share values and goals such as the development of democratic forms of government, commitment to gender equity, consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.
We advocate for closer cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Accordingly, we are going to support the proposal for recommendations on the European Union's Strategic Partnership with Mexico, which will be put before Parliament this very morning.

the European Guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate this access and which has been included in the report.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Bokland has explained, is very timely given the Diplomatic Conference on the Ship Recycling Convention to be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Bloán not only for the question but also for the resolution he has prepared.

In the Popular Party, we are in favor of the fight against the bad practices and methods that have been used to shame ships, and therefore we support Mr. Brokland's Resolution proposal. However, there are some points that concern us.
The first is paragraph 3, which he also highlighted, stating that ships in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, consequently, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have tabled an amendment on this paragraph, as there are different interpretations within and outside the European Union, and we believe that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and not contradicted. However, it should be the future international agreement on ship dismantling that defines the details of its implementation.
The proposed Resolution also calls, in its aforementioned point, for a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us to be somewhat premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time when the system to be adopted for this financing has not yet been decided within the IMO. And I also believe that the European Commission does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point 15, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the state with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible state.
We do not believe it is within the Commission's purview to make this decision, which should also be determined by an international agreement.

The important thing is to ensure coherence between the future Convention on G Ship Recycling and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, taking into account not only the Basel Convention but also all existing legislation.

The Arctic region is one of the most fragile areas of our planet.
The consequences of unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The melting of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making it necessary to establish new global regulations to protect the Arctic, similar to those already in place for the Antarctic, while taking into account the differences that have been highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty is necessary among all involved parties, undoubtedly including the European Union, to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and multilaterally regulate navigation through the new maritime routes that are becoming accessible.
The Arctic Council, throughout its many years of existence, has been a model of cooperation in addressing shared challenges.

At this time of difficulties and uncertainty, we must raise the level of this spirit and this harmony to prevent the states in the region or other international actors from engaging in geopolitical disputes, forgetting what should be the common goal: the preservation of a great shared heritage.

Madam President, for once I am glad that the headline is not about Mr Tajani's visit, because Mr Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of Parliament and a European.
And as a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we European Parliamentarians feel regarding the implementation of Community law.

Now, in Parliament, we tend to criticize the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission for an impossible task, because all Community law and the entire application of Community law are based on indirect implementation.

In other words, the Commission has only a handful of officials at its headquarters where it receives some complaints and has some scope for action. However, at this time, there is also a tendency to limit budgetary powers, which means the Commission will not have the ability to act.
All Community law, the entire application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, and national officials.
And here, on this point, I do not think we can demand too much from the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission. And I believe that in Mrs Frazoni's report, there are some points that could be useful in achieving this implementation.
I am referring to those concerning the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the action of national courts.

money, and it did not have sufficient support. Here, we must also thank the European Commission for providing financial support for this court.

precisely for that reason, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this court remains permanently in history.

European Parliament, we insisted on the principles emphasized by the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, both Mr. Viesca and Mr. Deré, and this is the principle of Community competence.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this resolution and have requested to speak on this matter because I was a witness to what was presented as an expulsion but was, in reality, the kidnapping of our colleague Luis Herrrero.

Furthermore, I was able to verify that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation of opponents, threats, contempt for the dignity of individuals, and the tortuous use of justice, among other things, are common practices in Venezuela.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel's back and has led to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his that are cited in the Resolution and others that are not.
As is the case with Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well-known for its danger and, moreover, for having elected a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied with the help of others and, specifically, Citibank, he managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and moreover, he later lived a normal life helping those in greatest need.
Today, however, he languishes in a Caracas prison, illegally detained for two years without any formal charges.
Their only crime is being part of the economic oligarchy.
Another case is Nison Moreno, student leader at the University of the Andes, elected several times to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
In 2013, he won the elections to the current Federation's Interior and Justice Ministry, and this is his crime.
Today, he is accused of attempted homicide, violent harmful acts, and all this despite having been exonerated of previous accusations.

Situations like yours are an everyday occurrence in this country where the persecution of opponents, with the intent to exclude them from political life and discourage dissent, has become a part of daily life.

However, from here, it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be removed from office through the ballot box.
Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made in recent times, but despite all the advancements, the south of the Union is burning and burning increasingly more.
Therefore, the Resolution I adopt in this Parliament cannot be just another resolution that merely highlights the great concern we feel for others' misfortunes.
Forest fires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, regardless of the responsibilities that may exist in certain states or autonomous communities, the fact remains that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act swiftly and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are considerable.
Neither the victims, nor the suffered damages, nor the reforestation needs understand bureaucracy or can comprehend budgetary shortages.

Prioritization and action are essential. Acting in this case means modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding effective implementation.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.

I would like to begin by congratulating Ms. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be said loudly and clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food self-sufficiency should be. And in past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food self-sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture, therefore, cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to move his business forward, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction in the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to ensure direct aid to farmers, as well as reestablishing a policy for the management of agricultural markets that provides greater price stability. This would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships among the different actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, there is a need for a consumer information policy for Europeans that highlights the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which once resonated with such hope and illusion among the peoples of the world and inspired the finest youth of the international community.
What characterizes, however, at this moment, the dictatorship of the Castro brothers is the cruelty towards political and conscientious prisoners, the cruelty against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco in his death throes, with the mistreatment of political prisoners whom he also considered common criminals, his same obsessive contempt for the exiled.
Castro ends up like a tyrant and all enemies of freedom when they entrench themselves in power.
But we must save lives and stand in solidarity with those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who seek to restrict our freedoms.
Never again allow a person who fought for their rights and those of all to die in a Cuban prison or anywhere else, without our voice being raised loud and firm, demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old black construction worker, who merely demanded an improvement in prison conditions, died after six days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for advocating respect for human rights.
And during those seven years, he was mistreated, humiliated, and abandoned by his captors, all while the international community remained in a thick silence.
Other prisoners and human rights activists, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas, are now on hunger strike.

Today, we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems normal to acknowledge that Mexican women, both indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, thus far, the responses of Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and thus, it is accurate to speak of nearly absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides, a harsh but accurate term, given that almost all murders committed against women go unpunished.

Sir, it has taken standing on the brink of economic collapse for the heads of state and government to realize that the path forward is not one of increased nationalism, but rather, a deeper commitment to Europe.

Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder whether this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government. Because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance, and what is lacking is genuine government, if we wish to remain faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

Mr. President, in January 2012, four Spanish egg producers, accounting for around 30% of the total in my country, could disappear, resulting in a loss of production of 300,000 tons of eggs.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those two million tons, and we would only achieve their coverage by imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are far inferior to those of the European Union if we do not act with great intelligence.
This Directive from the year 99, which obligates us to increase the space in hen cages, demands that we act with intelligence and a pragmatic, possibility-oriented vision, because if not,

We will only succeed in weakening European production and providing third countries with additional trade opportunities, where the current space for action is infinitely worse than that which we have in the European Union.

This is a Directive that demands tremendous effort from European producers. In Spain, we estimate that it will increase costs by around 600 million euros. However, we must not forget that it also has an economic impact that extends to the by-product industry and the food industry as a whole.

I therefore call for the support of your lordships for the Popular Group's amendment to the second paragraph, where it is requested to seek a solution, at least for the responsible industrial operations that are proceeding with the transformation of their operations and that by January 2012 will be almost complete.

There is a need to support them in transforming these facilities and to give them time to complete this process, thereby avoiding irreparable harm to farms and preventing a sudden shortage situation in the community market, which would consequently drive up consumer prices.
It is a matter of respecting the Directive's aim to give the egg and hen-product industry an opportunity, while also upholding the right to animal welfare and consumers' right to a reasonable price.

President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favor, along with the rest of our group, but I cannot leave this place without making my concern clear, because certain elements have been included in this Directive.
the issue of organ transplants, which goes against the stance of the Environment Committee due to the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

Therefore, I make it clear and state that we will remain attentive to the implementation of this directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today is also European Day Against Sexual Violence.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the data is concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over 300 million people are involuntarily infected with a sexually transmitted disease each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, the increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among adolescents is concerning, due to an excessive deficit in education and information among our youth.

Indeed, as the Commission points out, there are diverse and significant inequalities in access to sexual health services across Europe, varying from country to country and within them, depending on the income level of citizens.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.

Only in five member states are there plans in this regard, but in all of them, it has been possible to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies, infections from sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions.
A common strategy that prioritizes prevention through education, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and improves accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A comprehensive and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to ensure every citizen's right to sexual health under the highest conditions of safety and hygiene.

In the context of strong social tensions, it is nothing short of heartening to witness the significant agreement achieved through Social Concertation in Spain between the Government, trade unions, and business associations.
This Agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such significant milestones have not been achieved in a long time.

Also take careful note of the arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish pact, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February 8.
The change then emphasized the need to extend coordination on a European scale and the necessity of having the voice and initiatives of trade unions in our Europe.
Thus it should be.

tempting a massive landing of immigrants, as is currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens to the Italian coast could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.

if it happens, we'll put our hand to our head, but the next day we'll forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, that the common immigration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to providing sufficient economic resources to make it effective.
Talking costs nothing, but action is required.
Do you truly believe that Frontex can currently guarantee the security of European borders?
I believe not.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide to seek a better future in Europe, but rather in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth, when speaking of a common European migration policy, today more necessary than ever.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is still normative that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equity among citizens are found in pension systems, or that due to the crisis, private pensions lost only 20% of their value in 2008 and still remain below required solvency levels to this day.

All this demonstrates that, at a time of inevitable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be approached in a comprehensive manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on natality or work-life balance.

Some equally ambitious policies on access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration, would also guarantee, from a demographic perspective, the sustainability of our pensions.

Lastly, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of the self-employed worker status in companies, as, generally speaking, these individuals are excluded from all types of social security contributions.
In my opinion, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers who are being demanded more to earn a decent pension, and who would also need to suffer less to access a decent job.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we are at a crucial moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories to enable their citizens to make the most of their unique territorial characteristics.
But to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that face the same challenges and issues.

This is the goal pursued by the European Union's Atlantic Strategy, a common perspective to tackle the shared challenges faced by the region's States, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with Strategy 2020 and the European Union's policies for the post-2013 period, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
However, ladies and gentlemen, above all, it is necessary for this strategy to be based on renewed multi-level governance, founded on closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local levels, Member States, the European Union, and stakeholders from the private sector and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, as we celebrate International Women's Day, remembering those who, a century ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have come a long way in these hundred years, but there is still much to be done, and true equality remains a dream, while discrimination against women is a harsh reality.

I believe that each one of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and hope for all the women who, in the Revolution in North Africa, are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half of a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it. And as long as that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many may not want to acknowledge it, it is a reality that there are women who earn half as much as men, that domestic violence disproportionately affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and I certainly promise to keep working.
Mr. President, I would like to express my agreement with the opinion of the members who have spoken this morning and who insist on respect for the Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest positive vote will depend on the European Council being willing to acknowledge the role of the aforementioned institutions.
Because the new mechanism we are discussing should be an important component of the economic governance led by the European Union.
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

Esteemed colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of those that reinforce and balance this delicate structure.
There are essential points that need improving, so we must send the report back to the Commission.

initial proposal was poor.

We have succeeded in rejecting the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article 4.

It must be stated clearly that achieving maximum harmonization by establishing the same level of protection in all Member States would result in a reduction of protection for many consumers, as some countries have a stronger tradition of safeguarding consumer rights.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, thereby allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses they consider unacceptable and invalid in consumer contracts.

Reverse the burden of proof in individual clauses, so that it is the merchants who must demonstrate that the clauses that deviate from the generally established norms have been individually negotiated, that contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and unambiguous manner.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonization regarding abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79 percent of traders believe that full harmonization in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, allow me, firstly, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Mrs. Gerhard on the excellent work done.
And a general reflection.
It is not about increasing protectionism, but rather about not curtailing already existing rights in some of the Member States.
Because if we aim to establish and promote an authentic internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must
establish a balance in parallel between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that enhance consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I welcome the fact that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to insist that the rights already established so far should not be cut back.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis could be an energy crisis, and moreover, either we are not doing the necessary homework to prevent it, or we are not acting at the necessary speed to avert it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on all of us to make a small gesture in the name of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off the lights for an hour, and many public administrations will follow suit.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are far away, or on insecure energies.
to help states build a new energy model in which renewable energies are at the heart of the new one.
We must also support the promotion of new consumption patterns, because there is no doubt that renewables and efficiencies are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I would like to appeal to all countries of the Union to join this call, this willingness of five of its states, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30%, because by doing so, we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of progress, freedom, and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, it has been to denounce violence against women, and I am here once again to combat it.

speaker at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us legislators to compel states to punish aggressors, in accordance with the severity of the crime, and also to assist the victims.

The first thing is to not remain silent, and the second is to get to work, since, although we have been talking about gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something we are doing wrong, and therefore, it is time to forget demagoguery and to move from words to action, providing more help and necessary support so that women can live with dignity and security.
let all the victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until together we manage to defeat this.
enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me as well.
Mr. President, thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner, I agree with you that we must listen to citizens and regain trust in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a great day for Europe and European social construction.

Because, with the approval of these reports, we not only move forward towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we also thereby respond to the demands of citizens who call for progress towards more Europe and the strengthening of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and transform the European economy into a highly competitive social market economy, creating sustainable growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, placing citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthening their social rights.
Lastly, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health as well.

A disease against which we were fighting through the use of activated vaccines, which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal movement, because the use of these vaccines can lead to unwanted virus circulation in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, the use of the vaccine was limited, and vaccination was restricted in the areas where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for livestock farmers: on the one hand, the disease, and on the other, the restrictions.

But all these problems seem to be preventable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to avoiding the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies that are truly essential for prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the Directive to allow its use, and moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and Gentlemen, compliance with what our treaties stipulate, especially regarding the correspondence tables, cannot be an excuse for this regulation not to enter into force before the summer, because with our delay, and theirs, we would only be harming livestock farmers.

Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has carried out following the complaint lodged by FPEex, the Spanish Organization of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office.

I believe the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the European Commission, if it had already started working a long time ago, to clarify the functioning of the entry price system with regard to, at least, the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to address potential loopholes that may arise from the entry-price regulation currently in force, but it has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without first resolving the flaws in the existing import regime.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is high time the European Commission took its responsibilities seriously and began investigating where fraud is taking place, eventually requesting the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that under no circumstances should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without first resolving the details we have outlined.

Our goal is not to halt the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that such agreements do not severely harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in those agreements are respected.

As regards the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector merely requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out, and this is only possible through a reform of the entry price regime currently in force.
Until we have a new entry price system, we cannot have a new agreement with Morocco.
we will be able to ratify that agreement which the commission has already closed

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, discussing this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it has involved these measures that require the green light from the World Trade Organization, and the Commission's preliminary proposal sent to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.

European industry and, in a very special way, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain, are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to ascertain that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade are likely unable to be addressed with the urgency these acts require, which is why we must learn from this for the future.
To Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposals, as they do not take into account the effects of the European industry regarding the application deadlines for sensitive products.
I would even delay the implementation of these measures as they do not align with the pending text to be approved by the WTO. We would be past the deadline.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and conclude that we must vote no.
Mr. President, I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.
This is an agreement that we all should applaud, as it impacts the daily lives of all citizens. However, with the constructive spirit that defines me, I would like to make a few clarifications.

for consumers, regarding the components of textile products. Comprehensive information will be of no use if citizens are unable to decipher it.

Therefore, we should be much more ambitious and strive for size harmonization.
Mr. President, three notes on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and hold great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we notice that the actions taken by the Safety Authority and the Commission have been weak, lackluster, and imprecise. They have failed to coordinate or provide effective leadership.
zero, those affected are entitled to prompt economic compensation.

The lost honor must be reclaimed, a pleasing expression to the German writer Heinrich Bell. The lost honor of cucumber producers must be reclaimed.
Europe is the ideal setting for this.
Mr. President, firstly, I am compelled to express my sincere regret for the 23 victims who have already lost their lives, 22 in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be acknowledged as the most compelling evidence that the European Union needs to significantly improve its food alert system and internal coordination.
The involved member states have shown slowness, ineffectiveness, and inaction. At this point, even after 23 deaths, we still do not know the source of the problem.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the present one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and destruction of jobs that were previously secure.

stable unemployment, a sense of powerlessness, and of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population, because while you in the Commission were echoing irresponsible statements by regional authorities,

German consumers were very misinformed and rather irresponsible, naming specific Spanish farms. Meanwhile, the population remained exposed to the bacteria without realizing it, thinking they were avoiding it. Citizens were more exposed than ever to consuming something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Agriculture Council meeting in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., propose to ministers that part of the 2.5 billion euros available as unused remnants of the Common Agricultural Policy be utilized.
those two thousand five hundred million euros to repair, as much as possible, the damages incurred.

To achieve this, it is necessary to find a legal loophole that allows it, a legal loophole that has been found on previous occasions, such as with mad cow disease or dioxins, and which should be found now.
Therefore, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, today in Luxembourg you must rise to the occasion and assume your responsibility.

German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should undoubtedly support this economic solution from the outset and also fund, with their own resources, communication campaigns to restore consumer trust in self-fruitful productions.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring the dead back to life, and hopefully, what is being done will prevent more deaths and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We do not know the causes for certain, but we do know some things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state on another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her health minister have displayed in frequently addressing other states, if translated into diligence and effectiveness in coordination, would have prevented some of the events that have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a state, which has been the Spanish state, and for the most important sector of agriculture, driving thousands of people and small businesses to ruin and discrediting the economy for a long time.
I request that you go to the Council and demand full compensation for those affected, as we cannot ask for the lives of the deceased.
that the control systems be reviewed.
And that Mrs. Merkel be held accountable.
that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
And hold him accountable for the damage he has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
You cannot ignore your responsibilities.
You cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to cause the harm you have inflicted.

A little more humility, a little better management, and a little less conservatism would have gone a long way in preventing this crisis from spiraling out of control, and Spain and other southern farmers would not have had to endure its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because in Spain, we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, the Council, and the German state.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health issue, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has stated, and in response, we have sought to find someone to blame rather than the root cause.

The system has failed. We have twenty dead, 1600 affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And, appealing to a principle of precaution, without scientific basis—I repeat, without scientific basis, Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and Gentlemen, the Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
two were not contaminated. I repeat this because some contrary versions have been heard around here.
But to show you the importance of what these words have stirred up, three hundred thousand jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree, Commissioner, it knows no borders. We are asking for responsibility for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at this moment, it has a higher number of affected individuals. But Spain is not at fault.
We demand reparations.
And what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to report to the German authorities that they unjustly and precipitously accused Spanish cucumbers, and specifically the cooperatives in Málaga and Almería, which were model farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families wonder why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not just in Andalusia, but across the entire agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will find a swift solution, I call on the Commission to demand, when it speaks with the Council today, immediate economic and moral measures for all producers in Andalusia and across Europe who are looking to us with indignation but with hope.
Instead of prioritizing European research and collaboration, German authorities have slandered and harmed Cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the harm caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
It is intolerable how Mrs. Merkel treats the southern countries in matters of agriculture and finances as well.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Deauwe and Col.
none of that lacks moral credibility.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and another country share our reluctance to readily accept the so-called eurovignette.

The coincidence of the critique stems from our status as peripheral countries, which, ultimately, will be the ones to pay this unique levy that will be collected by the central European Union states with geographical centrality.
The rationale behind the Eurovignette scheme is fraught with significant contradictions, and the supporting argument grows weaker by the day.

Although it is accepted as a starting point that the rationality of internalizing external costs should be considered, in the end, it does not hold that, in order to alleviate congestion, only heavy vehicles should be penalized, excluding private cars, in the same way that the old motto of "the polluter pays" is applied with clear discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Roviñeta, which was envisioned as a source of infrastructure funding, in the end, only 15% will be allocated to the financing of European networks, and not mandatorily.

but rather as a simple recommendation, so that the incumbent Minister of Finance will decide on the funds collected for the purpose he deems most convenient for his country's interests within the broad chapter of infrastructures.
The final result will be nothing less than another blow to road freight transport, which, as of now, is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much harsher in the context of an economic crisis.

In that regard, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could further deteriorate the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new additional costs.

The food crisis, which has been recklessly attributed to Spanish products, has resulted in unfair penalties and substantial losses for those very sectors it penalizes: transporters of goods and prime crop farmers.
are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish Federation of the European Party will vote against this draft initiative.

You will all understand, dear colleagues, that upon assuming the presidency of this session, I express to you my pain and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is not perfect; it cannot by itself resolve the problems of a sector facing structural issues, exacerbated by the economic context we are experiencing, which presents cyclical challenges.
But this Regulation, while not perfect, is a decisive step forward in the right direction.

Because if in recent times we have all realized that there is no such thing as a perfect market, it was highly necessary to incorporate into this scenario, where we are also dealing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements we could and the protection of our producers.

It was highly necessary for us to allow the enforcement of contracts with a minimum term and a maximum volume, at least as a defensive tool, because, of course, our producers do not approach distribution, intermediaries, or collectors with the same negotiating strength.
Many things remain to be done.
We will need to improve safety nets and make them more agile and effective.
We must strive to further strengthen the sector's position in the value chain, ensure there is no quota distribution especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But without a doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers will be able to see this Parliament defending their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their labor.
has aptly pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which increases quotas for certain fruit and vegetable products, makes absolutely no sense when the figures of the current agreement are not respected.

It is worth recalling that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Traders denounced to the Committee on Petitions, precisely of this Parliament, the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price below the agreed market rate.
Illegal situations such as the one described place European farmers in a position of competitive disadvantage.
It should be added that our farmers must adhere to rigorous environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will address the issue of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory, and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
furthermore constitutes an area over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, one that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices. I support an agreement that combats dumping, does not exploit Moroccan farmers, and above all, uplifts our European farmers.
This is not, of course, this agreement.

In 2021, the Petition Committee of the European Parliament requested that the European Commission proceed with a modification of the entry price regime for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a regime that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of productions from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
mainly they are Moroccan tomatoes.

This, this fraud, is resolved by amending the Implementing Regulations for the Common Organization of Agricultural Markets, because, with the January alignment, the problem is not resolved, Commissioner.

For several years now, I have been advocating within the Popular Party the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union is equipped with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the Agreement in force.
The European Commission argues that it is the member states that must ensure the control of imports.

However, what the Commission tells us is that the entry price regime is in force, and the one in force prevents national customs authorities from correctly tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

amend the implementing regulations for the CMO for agricultural products, and we will have resolved part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I wish to pay tribute today to all women who, despite the significant progress made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that gender equality is still a long way off.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in rural areas whose labor is overlooked.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Just this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
And now it's time to say it loud and clear, to say it softly and firmly.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims' Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
We also have to say, and I would like to remind you, that motherhood continues to be an obstacle to women's progression, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope, and along with many women, with the increasing support of men, we must advance on the path towards equality, opportunities, rights, and also responsibilities.
We have come a long way, but there is much to be done.
I must admit that I do not fully and deeply believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something needs to be done, and I agree.

many of my colleagues and, of course, with Ms. Reding, in opening this debate and moving forward on this path so that women can reclaim the place they deserve. You can count on my support in this endeavor.

Mr. President, in a context of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health, and in which, as is the case in the community where I live, research centers such as the Prince Felipe Center, specialized in diabetes, are left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever and is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a Council recommendation that tells states they must increase research, including with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize the health of individuals above all else, and in this case, investigate, coordinate, and develop national programs led by the Commission, demanding results. Addressing diabetes is about ensuring the quality of life for Europeans and safeguarding their own lives.

If we dedicate more funds to this, some people may take a little longer to receive payment, but undoubtedly, those who are currently facing issues will have a better quality of life. As States, as the Council, and as the Commission, we will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to ensure the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, among the many issues this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions rights market, a market that was indeed born with flaws.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have led to a drastic reduction in the price of carbon. In other words, this price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is urgent, therefore, to reform the design of a policy on this market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, there is an incentive to increase emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and what is worse, they will continue with business as usual.
The funding of important projects, such as, for example, those related to energy efficiency or carbon capture plants, will be put at risk.
This is the risk.
It is our responsibility, along with the Commission and the Parliament, to swear to it.
Mr. President, few refugees are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has only just begun this experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent need.
The members of parliament have verified this firsthand during their visit to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria. The news that reached us promptly from Tunisia also confirms this.
Another institutional aspect is the balance of power between the Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the valiant Ruiz Tabares, is among many fine parliamentarians, but few possess the same tenacity as Ruiz.
Mr. Tas has advocated for the European Parliament to retain the new powers acquired following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by GNUR, without which success would not have been possible either.
AgNUR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so desperately needed.
And lastly, many thanks to the Commissioner, and I hope that we can also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of advancing the asylum package in the coming month.

The European social model, of which we are so proud, is not based solely on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balances between employers and employees within companies.

the labor reform approved by the Spanish government without dialogue and consensus breaks with this social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 strategy, both in terms of job creation and the quality of employment.
A labor reform by itself does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave.
And with this reform, where 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be covered by collective bargaining agreements, they can be dismissed due to a decrease in company income or

employers will be able to unilaterally modify their schedules. What is clear is that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform that attacks the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to workers' conditions deserves a general strike, such as the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain, in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.

That is why we have fundamentally requested two things.

first, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the formulation and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of
agriculture among the sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage in order to also access the deductions allowed in the CO2 emissions trading scheme.

We are living through a major controversy that inevitably revolves around the concepts of austerity and growth.
If one hears the noise that is being generated, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these times.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the pact known as the Stability and Growth Pact has been in force since 1997.

Therefore, a large part of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as regional cohesion and research policies, are growth-oriented policies that aim to achieve the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I address the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest chance of being heard, there is no complex on our part when engaging in this debate, which we can approach with our heads held high.

We all know that the 20th anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.

It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We are aware that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it challenging to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This compels us to address the issue of vulnerability through a cross-cutting analysis that takes into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
An ambitious proposal, by itself, is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the market.
information they receive, or the options available to them, or their lack of awareness of existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislations to ensure adequate protection.

Go beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level of complexity has been shown to be higher and where consumers register the largest number of complaints. The financial sector, due to its complexity, implies that, potentially, any consumer can become vulnerable.

For this reason, the financial services industry is called upon to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, abundant in clear explanations and using direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising.

Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commission for the work done, the rapporteurs, and the speakers in the debate.

In general terms, we are faced with a necessary and good G+ Regulation, specifically in certain actions related to enforcing import rules for textile products that could harm European Union production.
However, we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of the GSP from determining two countries classified as upper-middle-income countries, countries such as those in Latin America.
What about these middle-income countries with poorly diversified exports?
Why not introduce a diversification criterion for exports?
Because in this way, two speeds could emerge: countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we should support a transition period, and amendments will be tabled with this transition period to adapt to this situation in these countries and provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

I already supported Mrs. Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo along with other parliamentarians, and indeed, I verified that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest willingness to practice democracy and participate in it.

Madam President, since I entered this parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
That is the silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls around the world, seven million, I repeat, seven million.
An unbearable figure for those who stop to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which hide behind the disguise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of them false.

The truth is that female genital mutilation, practiced preferably on girls of two or even one year of age, can lead to death from hemorrhagic shock and, at best, cause and result in severe psychological sequelae due to the trauma.
From Europe, we must strive with all our might to eradicate this human rights violation, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
This, ladies and gentlemen, is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls, and this treatment of villainy also exists in Europe.
To achieve this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available to our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
girls in Europe, punishing those who carry it out, so that European law speaks with one voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop, because we owe it to the seven million mutilated women.

Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to highlight the excellent work of Ms. Macagan, the rapporteur, as well as the rest of the shadow rapporteurs, for reaching this agreement.
Agreed on first reading, which was very important, as the regulations we had adopted in 2010 were coming into force and needed to be fine-tuned.
Not because it was the legislation, the legislation was very good, but as has been said, the recent events, well-known to all, occurred and demonstrated that there was a certain...
A lagoon that needed to be corrected to prevent recurrence, and it was necessary to strengthen specific points of surveillance and drug safety once they were marketed.

Therefore, from now on, as has been stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicine who do not renew, withdraw, or request the withdrawal or suspension of the authorization will be subject to...
obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of the authorization of a medicine.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Moreover, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all concerned member states where this medication is marketed must be informed.
Everything will enhance transparency and security without overly burdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.
The second significant amendment achieved is that all authorized products subject to post-authorization safety studies are automatically included in a list of products under this monitoring.
Lastly, we cannot forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and therefore this Plenary should adopt this proposal.

The work of the rapporteur, Mr. President, is very good, but I would like to take this opportunity to say, here in this forum, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can attest.
We forget what Puffendorf already taught, that general laws should be few and their meaning must be correctly understood.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must use all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, filled with neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it creates a sinister web where pitfalls lurk and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to communicate them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even the professionals of the law, judges, and lawyers themselves to become desperate before our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way to demonstrate respect for the citizen.

Mr. President, there exists, esteemed colleagues, an old principle that has transitioned from the legal to the political realm, and that is pacta sunt servanda, meaning agreements are to be fulfilled.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the June European Council to address the crisis that affects us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and they have positively received decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro irreversibly.
The European Council observed last week, ladies and gentlemen, undeniably contains positive aspects. The conclusions regarding progress towards a banking union are satisfactory.
It is also positive that an agreement has been reached on the launch of the banking supervisor. Finally, it is appropriate that the launch be entrusted to the Ministers of Finance of the Eurozone.
But they will allow you to make a critical judgment based on the biased interpretations that have been made of it in a one-sided manner.

It is not admissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that could distort the mandate given to the Ministers of Economy. Likewise, we do not applaud matters that were not even discussed being presented as agreements.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism, which must cover all financial entities.
A common framework for deposit guarantees and a crisis resolution mechanism are also required.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.

Sir, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common security and defense policy.
It is a clear sign of the belief that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in contrast to the minority and hygrosceptic sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Danjián, to whom I would like to express my gratitude for his consensus-seeking spirit during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Social Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European Defense Strategy.
We have also emphasized that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
It is that of cybersecurity and cyber defense, reports that we also discuss today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European Cybersecurity Strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, where Member States are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is when European projects are most necessary.
That is why it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is currently facing significant challenges.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defence, and do so with President Van Rompuy's project for the December 2013 Council.

Ladies and Gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with far fewer resources, especially if what exists is distributed unjustly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that would simply mean the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity. And this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, which deserves credit for its efforts in outlining a different approach.

And at this point, emphasizing the need for unity and shared efforts, I would like to thank Mr. Barroso for making a forceful statement the other day in Cádiz regarding the interpretation of the Treaties in the face of an overly restrictive scenario within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State secedes as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, will not be affected in any way by the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself.

I hope, Mr. Vice-President, in the absence of the Mr. President, that this can be noted and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the assurance of all.
